reviewText: Video  quality good.Sound level not the best. Plot very good. Acting excellent. A movie made in a time when morals, manners, properness, modesty, chivalry, character, honor and righteousness reigned supreme. Unlike today where none of the above applies.Thus: for those who abhor movies made today; but love righteous movies from an era gone forever; you will like this one I believe.

reviewText: Excellent restoration of a great 1950's classic. The Moving Picture Archive has done an excellent job on both sound and video quality for this movie. Great suspense, and a surprise ending will keep you captivated throughout the entire film!Ritchie (Raymond Burr) runs a narcotics smuggling operation to the USA from Mexico, which the US federal government have unsuccessfully tried to stop. Ritchie's careful operating procedures prevent the US authorities from finding out the identities of his sources or customers. As a last resort, Haley (Claire Trevor), an LAPD officer, is sent undercover to Mexico to charm her way into Ritchie's confidence.Once there, Haley manages to establish contact with Ritchie's gang, but is kidnapped by Macklin (Fred MacMurray), a hoodlum working for a rival of Ritchie's, who also steals a load of Ritchie's narcotics. Haley plays along and joins Macklin on a smuggling trip for the stolen narcotics, with Ritchie in hot pursuit.At the border crossing, Macklin has plans to turn in Haley as a narcotics smuggler, not realizing she works for the LAPD. Haley has similar plans to turn Macklin in to the authorities as a drug smuggler.The ending will surprise you, as well as the fiery love affair which blossoms between these two undercover agents.
summary: 'She Has Excellent Equipment, and Doesn't Hesitate To Use It'
Title: N/A

reviewText: A female LAPD officer convinces her Captain to let her be the inside man in a cross-border investigation on a Mexican drug ring. She flirts her way into the syndicate boss's room via one of his lackluster flunkies and finds herself caught in the middle of a heist. Some other American grabs the drugs and her to get more information. A chase ensues and the showdown ends up in Los Angeles, at the L.A. Zoo circa 1950. Fred MacMurray is so great in these old roles. Amazing in Double Indemnity, but also in Honeymoon in Bali. This is a little bit slow to develop because it's all escape and very little plot.
summary: Teensy Bit Slow but a Great Movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: Like many "B" movies from the 1950's, the acting by the star players is very good; the script has the usual mixture of clichés; the cinematography is very well done; and the simple romantic elements are thrown in to please the general audiences of that era.I recommend it because it is entertaining and one sees some of the witty charm of Claire Trevor and Fred MacMurray.
Title: N/A

reviewText: How pleasurable it is to watch the old  noir movies again.  Fred MacMurray has always been a favorite  of mine and Claire Trevor was very good in her role.  The plot was plausible and the romantic tension, for some reason,  always seemed more realistic in the movies of the forties and fifties. Possibly because it was more subtle. NOIR should always be around. I hope. Susan
